deliberation: Considered whether 'stand on your feet' is merely physical or also metaphorical for readiness; context in v.2 shows an actual change of posture, so I treated it as primarily literal. The vocative 'בן־אדם' functions as a fixed idiomatic designation for Ezekiel as a mere human in contrast to the divine speaker, so I treated that as a metonymic/idiomatic expression.

target: individual human being in contrast to God
ground: sharing the nature and limitations of humanity
creaturely, mortal status as opposed to divine
the human side of the divine–human relationship
posture: humbling address that emphasizes Ezekiel’s lowly status
status-lowering, contrastive designation
prophetic commissioning discourse
instances.explanation: The phrase 'בן־אדם' is an idiomatic way of saying 'human/mortal', using 'son of man' (offspring of a human) metonymically for one who shares human, and thus limited, nature in contrast to the divine speaker.

deliberation: Reviewed 'a spirit entered into me and set me upon my feet' and considered whether 'spirit' is a metaphor for courage or strength. In Ezekiel, however, 'רוּחַ' regularly denotes the actual divine Spirit/power acting on the prophet within a visionary context, not merely a figurative 'inner mood.' The setting is a theophanic vision with a real change of posture described, so I judged the verse to be functioning narratively, not as a deliberate metaphor or simile.

Considered the pejorative phrasing 'nation of rebels' and the use of 'גּוֹיִם' for Israel, but these are evaluative rather than clearly figurative in this context. The one strongly idiomatic element is the temporal phrase 'עַד־עֶצֶם הַיּוֹם הַזֶּה', literally 'until the bone/essence of this day,' a standard Hebrew idiom intensifying 'to this very day.'

instances.english_text: to this very day (lit. until the bone/essence of this day)
target: the continuing duration of Israel’s rebellion
a specific stretch of time up to the present moment
vehicle: a body-part/essence standing for the whole day
ground: the 'essence' or 'core' stands for the entirety and exactness of the day
intensification of the idea 'this very same day'
using part/essence language to stress the precise present moment
posture: emphasizing the unbroken persistence of rebellion
intensive temporal idiom, not neutral description
prophetic stressing of ongoing guilt in historical perspective
instances.explanation: The phrase literally speaks of the 'bone/essence of this day,' using 'עֶצֶם' metonymically for the very substance or selfsame nature of the day, forming an idiom meaning 'to this very day' and intensifying the continuity of Israel’s defiance.

deliberation: Focused on the descriptors 'קְשֵׁי פָנִים' and 'חִזְקֵי־לֵב'. Both are conventional Hebrew expressions but still rely on physical imagery (hard face, strong/firm heart) mapped onto moral/psychological traits (shamelessness, stubbornness). I treated them as two distinct but closely related metaphors.

instances.english_text: brazen of face (lit. hard of face)
vehicle: physical properties of objects or body parts
ground: hardness suggests resistance to change and lack of soft responsiveness
an unyielding 'face' conveys shameless defiance
mapping physical rigidity onto moral obstinacy
posture: condemning their shameless defiance before God
evaluative, invective metaphor
prophetic critique of the people’s moral state
instances.explanation: Describing them as 'hard of face' uses physical hardness as a metaphor for shameless, unyielding defiance; their 'face' (public stance) is imagined as rigid, unable or unwilling to soften in response to God.

instances.english_text: stubborn of heart (lit. strong of heart)
target: their inner will and responsiveness to God
the decision-making core of the person
ground: a 'strong' heart suggests toughness and resistance to influence
inner core that does not bend or yield
physical strength mapped to moral intractability
posture: depicting their inner life as resistant to God
negative evaluation of their interior stubbornness
prophetic exposure of inner rebellion
instances.explanation: Calling them 'strong of heart' metaphorically portrays their inner self as tough, unbending material, emphasizing their stubborn refusal to be moved by God’s word.

deliberation: Checked 'whether they listen or not' for hyperbole or idiom, but it functions as a straightforward concessive contrast. The expression 'בֵּית מְרִי' ('rebellious house') is Ezekiel’s characteristic label for Israel and uses 'house' for the people group, which is both idiomatic and metonymic.

target: the people of Israel as a community
the covenant group characterized by rebellion
vehicle: a social unit defined by shared identity
ground: a 'house' commonly stands for the family or lineage inhabiting it
the group as a whole is marked by rebellion as its defining trait
using a household label to sum up corporate character
posture: branding the entire community with a negative identity
metonymic label used as prophetic indictment
covenant lawsuit rhetoric
instances.explanation: The phrase 'rebellious house' uses 'house' metonymically for the people who belong to it, forming an idiomatic label that characterizes Israel collectively as defined by rebellion.

deliberation: This verse is rich in imagery. 'Thistles and thorns press against you' (from 'סָרָבִים וְסַלּוֹנִים אֹתָךְ') and 'you sit/dwell among scorpions' are not literal horticultural or zoological descriptions but metaphorical depictions of hostile, injurious people around the prophet. The repetition of 'בֵּית מְרִי' at the end reuses the metonymic/idiomatic label from v.5.

instances.english_text: though thistles and thorns press against you
vehicle: hazardous elements in the natural world
ground: both hostile people and thorns wound and cause pain on contact
they obstruct, scratch, and make the path difficult
imagery of prickliness conveys the pain and difficulty of the prophet’s task
posture: warning Ezekiel that opposition will be sharp and painful
realistic but vivid portrayal of his dangerous environment
prophetic commissioning under threat
instances.explanation: The surrounding people are likened to 'thistles and thorns' that press against Ezekiel, picturing their opposition as painful and obstructive, like walking through dense, prickly undergrowth.

instances.english_text: and you sit upon scorpions / you dwell among scorpions
target: constant exposure to treacherous, harmful people
the social–spiritual environment of his ministry
ground: both scorpions and the people around him can suddenly inflict severe pain or harm
conveys latent, ever-present danger
imagery of venom and sting applied to verbal and social hostility
posture: underscoring the perilous nature of his calling
heightening the sense of danger to emphasize the need for courage
commissioning rhetoric in vivid metaphor
instances.explanation: To say that Ezekiel 'dwells among scorpions' metaphorically portrays his neighbors as venomous creatures whose attacks (verbal or otherwise) can be as painful and dangerous as scorpion stings.

instances.english_text: for they are a rebellious breed / rebellious house
target: the people of Israel addressed by Ezekiel
the covenant community in its corporate identity
vehicle: domestic structure implying a group of occupants
ground: a 'house' commonly stands for the family/lineage it shelters
using one term to sum up the collective and its defining trait of rebellion
metonymic label fusing group and characteristic
posture: reaffirming their settled identity as rebellious
compressing a long history of disobedience into a sharp label
prophetic indictment through naming
instances.explanation: Again 'rebellious house' uses 'house' as a metonym for the people themselves, forming an idiomatic label for Israel as a community whose hallmark is rebellion.

deliberation: Re-examined 'whether they listen or not, for they are rebellious.' The statement is strongly evaluative but does not employ overt metaphor, simile, or other imagery beyond the straightforward adjective 'rebellious'; no 'house' terminology appears here. I therefore treated the verse as lacking a discrete figurative expression under the requested categories.

Here 'בֶּן־אָדָם' reoccurs but I did not duplicate that analysis. The explicit comparison 'אַל־תְּהִי־מֶרִי כְּבֵית הַמֶּרִי' uses 'כְּ' ('like/as') and so constitutes a clear simile. The command 'open your mouth and eat what I give you' is preparatory to the scroll-eating sign-act, where consuming a scroll stands symbolically for internalizing the divine message, so I treated it as metaphorical action, even though in the vision Ezekiel literally does eat.

instances.english_text: Do not be rebellious like that rebellious breed / house
target: Ezekiel’s potential behavior and stance toward God’s command
a single prophet’s obedience or rebellion
ground: similar patterns of disobedience could be shared by prophet and people
Ezekiel is warned not to mirror the community’s characteristic rebellion
comparison highlights the danger of assimilation to the group’s behavior
posture: exhorting Ezekiel to distinguish himself from his people
using comparison as moral warning
prophetic pedagogy through simile
instances.explanation: By saying 'do not be rebellious like the rebellious house,' God explicitly compares Ezekiel’s potential response to the established behavior of Israel, using the previously coined metonymic label 'rebellious house' as the vehicle in a simile to warn him against similar disobedience.

instances.hebrew_text: פְּצֵה פִיךָ וֶאֱכֹל אֵת אֲשֶׁר־אֲנִי נֹתֵן אֵלֶיךָ

using a symbolic action metaphor typical of prophetic sign-acts

instances.explanation: The command to 'open your mouth and eat' what God gives anticipates the eating of the scroll and uses the physical process of eating as a metaphor for taking God’s words deeply into oneself so that they shape the prophet from within.

deliberation: Considered whether the vision of a 'hand' stretched out is literal within the visionary world or figurative. In prophetic literature, a disembodied or divine 'hand' often functions metonymically for God’s agency; here no subject other than the divine context is supplied, so the 'hand sent to me' is best read as an anthropomorphic metonymy for God’s action in presenting the scroll.

instances.english_text: there was a hand stretched out to me
target: God’s act of giving the scroll to Ezekiel
vehicle: the bodily instrument of giving and acting
ground: a hand is the normal means by which a person extends something to another
God’s action is pictured as if performed by a human hand
the concrete image makes divine agency vivid and graspable
posture: depicting divine agency in human bodily terms
using anthropomorphic metonymy to mediate transcendence
visionary representation of God’s giving of his word
instances.explanation: The 'hand' that is 'sent' to Ezekiel is an anthropomorphic metonymy: a human hand stands for the divine action of extending the scroll, making God’s otherwise invisible agency concrete in the vision.

deliberation: Examined the description of the scroll written 'front and back' and the list 'lamentations, dirges, and woes.' The fullness of writing has symbolic significance for later interpretation, but the wording itself is descriptive rather than figurative (no explicit metaphor, simile, or idiom). The triplet names genres of judgment oracles, not metaphorical designations here, so I treated the verse as lacking a discrete figurative expression under the specified categories.
